references.title: Invasion of host cells by microsporidia
Induction of a rapid and strong antigen-specific
B-1 cell protective role in murine primary
Roles of LAMP-1 and LAMP-2 in lysosome biogenesis

sections.heading: 25 Abstract
sections.text:
26 Encephalitozoon cuniculi is an opportunistic intracellular pathogen that establishes a 27 balanced relationship with immunocompetent individuals depending on the activity of 28 their CD8+ T cells lymphocytes. However, lower resistance to experimental infection with 29 E. cuniculi was found in B-1 deficient mice (Xid), besides increased the number of CD8 30 T lymphocytes. Here, we evaluated the cytotoxic activity of CD8+ T lymphocytes from 31 Balb/c wild-type (WT) or Balb/c Xid mice (with B-1 cell deficiency) on the microbicidal 32 activity of macrophages challenged with E. cuniculi. CD8 T lymphocytes from WT or 33 Xid mice previously infected or not with E cuniculi were co-cultured with macrophages 34 challenged with E. cuniculi. We evaluated macrophages viability and microbicidal 35 activity, and proliferation, viability, and presence of activating molecules (CD62L, CD69, 36 and CD107a) in CD8 T lymphocytes. Macrophages co-cultured with CD8 T lymphocytes 37 from WT demonstrated high microbicidal activity. CD8 T lymphocytes obtained from 38 uninfected WT mice had a higher proliferative capacity and a higher expression of CD69 39 and LAMP-1-activating molecules compared to Xid CD8+ T lymphocytes. CD8 T 40 lymphocytes from infected Xid mice proliferated more than those from WT mice, 41 however, when the expression of the activating molecule CD69 associated with the 42 expression of CD62L was kept low. In conclusion, the absence of B-1 cells in Xid mice 43 might be associated with the lower expression of activating molecules in CD8+ T 44 lymphocytes and their cytotoxic activity. However, after a previous infection with E. 45 cuniculi, CD8 T lymphocytes were more effective in killing macrophages infected with 46 E. cuniculi.

3 47 48 Keywords: Xid mice; B-1 cells; CD8 T lymphocytes; encephalitozoonosis 49
under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license. preprint (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright

4 50 Introduction 51 52 Microsporidia are opportunistic, obligate intracellular parasites that affect vertebrate and 53 invertebrate hosts [1]. The phylum Microsporidia has at least 200 genera and more than 54 1,500 species, of which 17 species affect mammals, including domestic animals and 55 humans [2, 3] (Han et al., 2021; Mohamed et al., 2021). Microsporidian spores are 56 resistant and infective; they are usually ingested by susceptible hosts and infect host cells 57 by extruding their polar tubule, injecting the sporoplasm into the cytoplasm, which 58 initiates their development and proliferation [4, 5]. To survive, the pathogen fights against 59 the immune response using various adaptive evasion mechanisms. Encephalitozoon 60 cuniculi is used as a standard for studying the immune response in mice [6]. It infects 61 epithelial and endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and macrophages of various mammals, 62 including rabbits, rodents, carnivores, monkeys, several wild mammals, and humans [6]. 63 Several researchers have evaluated immunity against microsporidia, especially E. 64 cuniculi, in recent years, and highlighted the importance of adaptive immunity in 65 combating microsporidiosis [7, 8]. T cells protect against E. cuniculi infection [9, 10, 11]. 66 Some studies have shown that protective immunity against intraperitoneal (i.p.) infection 67 depends specifically on CD8 T cell immunity; TCD8–/– mice died after inoculation of the 68 pathogen, which caused severe and disseminated disease [12, 13, 14, 15] . In contrast, E. 69 cuniculi infection of CD4–/– mice did not result in any mortality [11]. Our group found 70 that several immunosuppressive doses of cyclophosphamide can increase the 71 susceptibility of mice to encephalitozoonosis by significantly reducing the population of 72 T lymphocytes [16]. 73 However, before acquired immunity is activated to control microsporidiosis, the innate 74 immune response must play its role in antigen preparation and presentation and milieu
under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license. preprint (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright
The copyright holder for thisthis version posted November 22, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.11.22.568300doi: bioRxiv preprint
5 75 modulation via the release of chemokines and cytokines, which subsequently activate 76 adaptive immune cells. Macrophages, dendritic cells, natural killer cells (NKs), and 77 innate-like lymphocytes are essential for eliciting responses against microsporidian 78 infections [8]. Our group has investigated the effect of B-1 cells on encephalitozoonosis. 79 B-1 cells are a part of innate immunity and constitute a distinct population from B (B-2) 80 cells due to their anatomical location, phenotype, self-renewal capacity, and ability to 81 produce natural antibodies [17]. Generally, B-1 cells are found in the pleural and 82 peritoneal cavities and express high levels of IgM and low levels of IgD and CD11b on 83 their surface [18]. B-1 cells play a key role in acquired and innate immunity. To assess 84 their role, Balb/c Xid mice (Xid) are used because they are carriers of Bruton's tyrosine 85 kinase (Btk) deficiency, which leads to B cell deficiency [19, 20]. 86 In another study, our group showed that Xid mice were more susceptible to infection by 87 E. cuniculi than wild-type (WT) mice, via the oral and intraperitoneal route. This lower 88 resistance was associated with B-1 cell deficiency since the adoptive transfer of these 89 cells to Xid mice promoted the increase in immune cell populations and resulted in greater 90 resistance to infection [21, 22]. We also showed that Xid mice treated with Cy 91 immunosuppression developed severe and disseminated encephalitozoonosis, which was 92 similar to that reported in the models with T-cell deficiency. However, populations of 93 TCD8+ and TCD4+ lymphocytes in the peritoneum were higher than those in WT mice, 94 which had milder disease [23]. B-1 cells influenced the composition of pulmonary 95 granuloma induced by BCG in mice [24] and it was demonstrated that B-1 cells induced 96 a large infiltrate of CD8+ T lymphocytes in grafts [25]. Additionally, it has been 97 suggested that peritoneal B-1 cells may also influence the immune response by activating 98 T cells without necessarily migrating to the lymphoid organ responsible for eliciting a 99 response [26].
under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license. preprint (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright
The copyright holder for thisthis version posted November 22, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.11.22.568300doi: bioRxiv preprint
6 100 We hypothesized that partial susceptibility of Xid mice to an infection may suggest an 101 inefficient function of T lymphocytes due to the absence of B-1 cells. Our aim was to 102 study the effects of CD8+ T lymphocytes obtained from WT mice (with B-1 cells) and 103 Xid mice (with B-1 cell deficiency) on the microbicidal activity of macrophages 104 challenged with E. cuniculi. 105 106 107 Methods 108 109 Ethics statement 110 All experiments involving animals were performed following the recommendations 111 outlined in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (Concea – Conselho 112 Nacional de Controlee m Experimentação Animal). All research protocols for animals 113 (number 016/17) were approved by the institutional animal use committee (Comissão de 114 Ética no Uso de Animais – CEUA) at Universidade Paulista - UNIP. We prioritized 115 minimizing the suffering and distress of animals during the study. 116 117 Encephalitozoon cuniculi spores 118 The spores of E. cuniculi (genotype I) (Waterborne Inc., New Orleans, LA, USA) used 119 in this study were previously cultivated in a rabbit kidney cell lineage (RK-13, ATCC 120 CCL-37) in RPMI medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (FCS-Sigma121 Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) and gentamicin at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere with 122 5% CO2. The spores were purified by centrifugation at 500 g for 20 min, and cellular 123 debris was excluded using 50% Percoll. The spores of E. cuniculi were counted using a 124 Neubauer chamber.
under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license. preprint (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright
The copyright holder for thisthis version posted November 22, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.11.22.568300doi: bioRxiv preprint
7 125 126 Animals 127 Isogenic, female, eight-week-old, and specific pathogen-free Balb/c WT and Xid mice 128 were obtained from the “Centro de Desenvolvimento de Modelos Experimentais para 129 Biologia e Medicina” (CEDEME) at Federal University of Sao Paulo (UNIFESP, in 130 Portuguese). The animals were placed in groups (uninfected or infected) and kept in 131 sterilized individual cages at the animal facility at Paulista University (UNIP), under 132 controlled conditions of temperature and humidity. All animals were provided water and 133 food ad libitum. 134 135 Macrophage culture and infection 136 We maintained RAW 264.7 macrophages in RPMI medium (Sigma-Aldrich, St Louis, 137 MO, USA) supplemented with 10% FCS (R10) at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere with 138 5% CO2. The cultures were maintained by periodically changing the R10 medium to 139 obtain macrophages. The medium was changed every two days until 70 to 80% 140 confluence was reached. 141 Macrophages were inoculated in 24-well plates (1×105 cells/well) in 300 µL of R10 142 medium and incubated for 4 h at 37 °C in an atmosphere containing 5% CO2. After 143 removing the supernatant, the cultures were infected with E. cuniculi spores at a 2:1 ratio 144 of E. cuniculi spores to each type of macrophage for 1 h. The experiments were performed 145 in quadruplicates. Before being co-cultured with CD8 T lymphocytes, the supernatant of 146 macrophages was removed, and the wells were washed with PBS to remove spores and 147 cellular debris. 148

8 149 Isolation of CD8 T lymphocytes 150 The CD8+ T cells from the splenocyte population were sorted by flow cytometry FACS 151 ARIA II at the Immunology Discipline of the Department of Microbiology and 152 Immunology of the Federal University of São Paulo (UNIFESP). WT or Xid mice 153 infected or not infected were administered ketamine (100 mg/mL), xylazine (20 mg/mL), 154 and fentanyl (0.05 mg/mL) intraperitoneally. After cardiorespiratory arrest, the animals 155 were washed with a chlorhexine solution and immersed in 70% alcohol. The spleens were 156 collected under sterile conditions and mechanically dissociated using a syringe plunger 157 and a 70 µm nylon mesh (cell strainer) in a PBS solution supplemented with 2% FBS 158 (PBS+FBS). After centrifugation, the supernatant was discarded, and 1 mL of hemolytic 159 buffer was added. After 2 min, 10 mL of PBS+FBS was added, and the samples were 160 centrifuged at 1,500 rpm for 5 min. Next, the samples were incubated for 20 min with 161 anti-CD16/CD32 antibodies to block Fc receptors under refrigeration. The cells were 162 washed with PBS+FBS and incubated with the monoclonal antibody anti-mouse CD8 T 163 conjugated to Fluorescein Isothiocyanate (FITC) (BD-Pharmingen, San Diego, CA), 164 which was suitable for determining the phenotype of CD8+ T cells. After the cells were 165 refrigerated for 20 min, they were washed and resuspended in 2 mL of PBS for cell sorting 166 using a flow cytometer (Supplementary figure). 167 168 Experimental Design 169 To understand the effects of B-1 cells on CD8 T lymphocytes, two experimental protocols 170 were used. Using the first protocol, naïve CD8+ T lymphocytes were collected from the 171 spleen of uninfected WT and Xid mice and separated by cell sorting. Using the second 172 protocol, primed CD8+ T lymphocytes were collected by cell sorting from WT and Xid 173 mice after 14 days of infection with 1×107 spores of E. cuniculi, by i.p. route . In both

9 174 protocols, CD8 T cells were co-cultured with E. cuniculi-infected macrophages for 36 h. 175 After incubation, we analyzed macrophages viability and their microbicidal potential 176 against E. cuniculi by measuring the proliferative capacity of the recovered spores to 177 develop in RK cell culture. For CD8 T lymphocytes, we evaluated the viability, 178 proliferative capacity, and activation profile of following the two protocols (Fig. 1). 179 180 Figure 1. Graphical representation of the experimental strategies. 181 Experimental design 1 - CD8+ T lymphocytes were collected from the spleens of Balb/c 182 or WT mice (with B-1 cells) and Xid (with B-1 cell deficiency). They were separated by 183 cell sorting and co-cultured with macrophages previously infected with spores of 184 Encephalitozoon cuniculi. After 36 h, the macrophages were tested for viability, the 185 spores were tested for proliferation, and CD8 T cells were analyzed for viability, 186 proliferation, and panel activation. Experimental design 2 - CD8+ T lymphocytes were 187 collected from the spleens of Balb/c or WT mice (with B-1 cells) and Xid (with B-1 cell 188 deficiency) infected with E. cuniculi spores. They were separated by cell sorting and co189 cultured with macrophages previously infected with the spores of E. cuniculi. After 36 h, 190 the macrophages were tested for viability, the spores were tested for proliferation, and 191 CD8 T cells were analyzed for viability, proliferation, and panel activation. 192 193 194 Evaluation of the phagocytosis of spores by fluorescence microscopy 195 Macrophages were labeled with the fluorescent dye PKH-26 (Sigma Aldrich, St. Louis, 196 MO, USA) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Briefly, after diluent C and 197 fluorophore were added to cells, the mixture was incubated for 5 min. After blocking with 198 5% FBS, the cells were washed and cultured in 24-well plates on glass coverslips for 4 h.

10
199 Then, macrophages were infected with spores of E. cuniculi labeled with the fluorescent 200 dye carboxyfluorescein succinimidyl ester (CFSE) in a 2:1 ratio and incubated for 1 h. In 201 different groups, lymphocytes from mice (WT or Xid, both uninfected) were added to 202 macrophages culture, according to the experimental design, and incubated for 36 h at
203 37C with 5% CO2. As a negative control, E. cuniculi infected macrophages were labeled. 204 After incubation, the coverslips were washed with PBS and fixed with 300 µL of 4% 205 paraformaldehyde for 20 min. Then, the coverslips were washed with PBS and mounted 206 on a glass slide using 5 µL of the mounting medium DAPI-Fluorishield (Sigma Aldrich, 207 St. Louis, MO, USA). All observations were performed using a Leica TCS SP8 confocal 208 microscope, and the LAS X program was used for analysis. 209
210 Viability of macrophages and CD8 T cells
211 Viability was analyzed with Kit 7AAD/Annexin (BD Pharmingen), according to the 212 manufacturer’s instructions. Before viability assay, the nonspecific Fc receptors from 213 macrophages or CD8 T cells were blocked with anti-CD16/32 antibodies and incubated 214 for 15 min. After washing with Mac’s buffer (0.5% BSA and 0.075% EDTA), the 215 macrophages were labeled with mouse anti-F4/80 monoclonal antibody conjugated to 216 phycoerythrin (PE) and CD8 T cells with FITC-conjugated mouse anti-CD8 monoclonal 217 antibody for 30 min at 4 °C. Once again, the washing with Mac’s buffer was performed. 218 After that, the cells were centrifuged and resuspended in the Kit buffer, followed by the 219 addition of 1 µL of annexin and 1 µL of 7AAD. After 15 min of incubation at room 220 temperature in the dark, the kit buffer was again added, and apoptosis quantification was 221 performed on an AccuriTMC6 flow cytometer (BD Biosciences, Mountain View, CA) 222 while collecting after 30 s from each of the tubes. 223

224 Lymphocyte proliferation assay 225 The CD8+ T lymphocytes from the spleens of WT and Xid mice (infected and uninfected) 226 were isolated and labeled with CFSE, following the manufacturer's instructions. Briefly, 227 1 µM CFSE was added to the lymphocytes and incubated at 37 °C for 10 min. Then, two 228 washes were performed with sterilized PBS. CFSE-CD8 T lymphocytes were co-cultured 229 with macrophages infected with E. cuniculi spores (described in Section 2.5) for 36 h at 230 37 °C with 5% CO2. After incubation, the supernatant containing the lymphocytes was 231 collected, centrifuged, and resuspended in 150 µL of PBS for analyzing the samples using 232 a flow cytometer (ACCURI C6 Sampler; BD Bioscience); the decrease in the CFSE 233 fluorescence intensity was used as a proliferation parameter. 234 235 Analysis of the cytotoxic activity 236 Macrophages infected with E. cuniculi (details in Section 2.5) were co-cultured with 237 CD8+ T lymphocytes from WT or Xid mice, previously separated by sorting, in a 5:1 ratio 238 (five lymphocytes to one macrophage). The cells were incubated at 37 °C with 5% CO2. 239 After 31 h, 10 µL of mouse anti-CD107a (LAMP1) monoclonal antibodies conjugated to 240 Phycoerythrin (PE) were added per well. After 1 h, 0.5 µL of monensin and 0.5 µL of 241 brefeldin were added to the final solution (500 µL) to block protein transport across the 242 cell membrane. Upon completion of the experiment after 36 h, the supernatant was 243 collected, the adhered macrophages were released using a cell scraper, and they were 244 added to the lymphocytes in the supernatant. After centrifugation at 200g for 5 minutes, 245 the anti-Fc receptors were added to cells, with the subsequent separation of the sediment 246 into two aliquots. In panel 1, the markers used included FITC-conjugated mouse anti247 CD8 monoclonal antibody, allophycocyanin (APC)-conjugated mouse anti-CD69 248 monoclonal antibody, and Peridinin Chlorophyll Protein Complex (PerCP)-conjugated

249 mouse monoclonal antibody (Cy5). The cells were incubated for 30 min under 250 refrigeration and away from light, washed and resuspended in 150 µL of PBS, and 251 analyzed using a flow cytometer. In panel 2, lymphocytes were labeled using interferon252 gamma (IFN-γ). Briefly, the samples were permeabilized with a 253 Fixation/Permeabilization solution (BD Citofix/Citoperm - Fixation/Permeabilization 254 kit) for 20 min and then washed with Perm/Wash buffer. Next, the cells were incubated 255 for 30 min with FITC-conjugated anti-mouse CD8, PerCP-conjugated anti-F4/80, and 256 APC-conjugated anti-IFN-γ antibodies. Finally, the cells were washed with Perm/Wash 257 buffer, resuspended in 150 µL of PBS, and analyzed using an Accuri BD flow cytometer. 258 259 Microbicidal activity 260 Macrophages infected with E. cuniculi spores at a 2:1 ratio were co-cultured with CD8+ 261 T lymphocytes from WT or Xid mice, at a lymphocyte-to-macrophage ratio of 5:1 under 262 controlled conditions (37 °C and 5% CO2). After 36 h, both types of cells were harvested 263 and disrupted by alternately exposing them to cold (ice bath) and heat (70 °C) treatment 264 for 20 s in each condition. The process was repeated 20 times for the complete disruption 265 of cells and release of intracellular spores. The total number of spores collected was 266 denoted as T0. To determine that the spores were viable, they were inoculated into RK267 13 cells and cultured for seven days. Following this, the cells were harvested and 268 disrupted, and the number of spores present (T7) was counted. The T7/T0 ratio (Ratio = 269 final number of T7 spores/initial number of T0 spores) was evaluated and indicated the 270 proliferation of spores. The averages of the ratios of each group were used to conduct the 271 statistical analysis. 272 273 Statistical analysis

274 All differences between groups were determined by paired t-tests. All values were
275 presented as the mean ±standard error of the mean (SEM) with a significance of  = 0.05 276 (p < 0.05). All graphs were plotted using “GraphPad Prism” version 5.0 for Windows® 277 (GraphPad Software Inc., La Jolla, CA, EUA).
278 279 Results 280 281 Co-cultures of infected macrophages and CD8 T lymphocytes 282 The spores, with oval shape and fluorescence green color, were internalized by 283 macrophages after 1 h of observation (Fig. 2A). However, after 36 h of incubation, in co284 cultures with CD8 T lymphocytes from WT and Xid mice, few spores were detected with 285 their characteristics preserved (Fig. 2B and 2C). Also, fewer intact spores with 286 fluorescence green were detected inside the macrophages. However, the presence of 287 orange vacuoles indicated that phagolysosomes were frequent, suggesting spore 288 degradation (Fig. 2B and 2C). The contact between CD8 T lymphocytes and macrophages 289 was also visible, indicating intercellular communication occurred (Fig. 2C). 290 291 Figure 2. Photomicrographs of E. cuniculi infected macrophages were or were not 292 co-cultured with CD8 T lymphocytes, obtained by confocal microscopy. 293 Macrophages incorporated with the PKH-26 dye (red) were infected with E. cuniculi 294 spores, stained with CFSE (green) for 1 h, and the slides were mounted with DAPI (blue). 295 (A) Macrophages incorporated with the PKH-26 dye (red) were infected with CFSE296 stained E. cuniculi spores (green) for 1 h, and the slides were mounted with DAPI (blue) 297 Note the presence of E. cuniculi spores inside macrophages after 1 h of infection (insert). 298 (B) Macrophages incorporated with the PKH-26 dye (red) were infected with the spores

299 of E. cuniculi stained with CFSE (green) for 1 h, and the slides were mounted with DAPI 300 (blue). Then, CD8+ T lymphocytes from WT mice were co-cultured with macrophages 301 for 36 h. (C) Macrophages incorporated with the PKH-26 dye (red) were infected with 302 the spores of E. cuniculi stained with CFSE (green) for 1 h, and the slides were mounted 303 with DAPI (blue). Then, CD8+ T lymphocytes from Xid mice were co-cultured with 304 macrophages for 36 h. Few intact spores were present inside macrophages. CD8 T 305 lymphocytes can be seen adhering to macrophages (arrow). 306 307 Previous infection with E. cuniculi reduced the viability of macrophages 308 The viability of macrophages co-cultured with CD8 T lymphocytes obtained from 309 uninfected WT and Xid mice was similar; around 90–95% of the cells were viable (Fig. 310 3A, 3B). Death due to apoptosis was twice as high as that due to necrosis in the two 311 groups of cells. However, the viability of macrophages co-cultured with CD8 T 312 lymphocytes from E. cuniculi infected Xid mice previously was lower (60–70%) (Fig. 313 3E, 3F) and most cells died due to apoptosis (Fig. 3G, 3H). These results suggested that 314 lymphocytes from Xid mice infected with E. cuniculi induced an increase in the apoptosis 315 of macrophages. 316 317 Figure 3. Viability analysis of CD8 T lymphocytes co-cultured with E. cuniculi318 challenged macrophages. 319 The viability of CD8 T lymphocytes from uninfected mice or those previously infected 320 with E. cuniculi was determined after co-culture with E. cuniculi-challenged 321 macrophages. (A-D) Macrophages challenged with E. cuniculi were co-cultured for 36 322 h with CD8 T lymphocytes collected from uninfected Balb/c (WT) and Xid mice. (E-H) 323 Macrophages challenged with E. cuniculi were co-cultured for 36 h with CD8 T

324 lymphocytes collected from E. cuniculi-infected Balb/c (WT) and Xid mice. (A) The 325 number of CD8 T lymphocytes. (B) The percentage of living CD8 T lymphocytes. (C) 326 The percentage of CD8 T lymphocytes undergoing necrosis. (D) The percentage of CD8 327 T lymphocytes undergoing apoptosis. (E) The number of CD8 T lymphocytes. (F) The 328 percentage of living CD8 T lymphocytes. (G) The percentage of CD8 T lymphocytes 329 undergoing necrosis. (H) The percentage of CD8 T lymphocytes undergoing apoptosis. 330 Statistical analysis: paired t-tests were conducted in triplicate; *** p < 0.001 and **** p 331 < 0.0001. 332 333 The spores recovered from the co-cultures of macrophages and CD8 T cells were 334 inoculated into RK cells. As E. cuniculi spores have a high affinity for RK cells, viable 335 spores could internalize the sporoplasm through the polar tubule and multiply inside these 336 cells. The results of the proliferation assay showed that the spores recovered from co337 cultures of macrophages with CD8 T lymphocytes from uninfected WT mice were not 338 viable (Fig. 4A), as the ratio between the spores inoculated in the RK cells to those 339 recovered was zero. This finding showed the high microbicidal capacity of the 340 macrophages in co-culture with CD8 T cells from WT uninfected mice. The proliferation 341 rate of spores recovered from co-cultures of macrophages with CD8 T lymphocytes from 342 uninfected Xid mice was high, i.e., the number of spores recovered from RK cell cultures 343 was 2–10 times greater than the number of spores initially inoculated, these results 344 confirmed the viability and subsequent multiplication of the spores in RK cells (Fig. 4A). 345 Our findings indicated a decrease in the microbicidal activity of macrophages that were 346 co-cultured with CD8 T lymphocytes from Xid mice. 347 The results of the proliferation assay performed for spores obtained from co-cultures with 348 lymphocytes from infected WT and Xid mice showed the opposite pattern. A higher

349 microbicidal activity was recorded in co-cultures with CD8 T lymphocytes from Xid mice 350 (Fig. 4B).
351
352 Figure 4. Proliferation ratio of spores obtained from macrophages co-cultured with 353 CD8 T lymphocytes. 354 After macrophages were co-cultured with CD8 T lymphocytes from Balb (WT) or Xid 355 (uninfected or infected) mice, the spores recovered from cultures with macrophages 356 challenged with E. cuniculi were counted (T0) and cultured in RK cells for seven days 357 (T7) to obtain the ratio of proliferation (T7/T0). (A) CD8 T lymphocytes from uninfected 358 Balb or Xid mice (Uninfected) were co-cultured with macrophages and challenged with 359 E. cuniculi. (B) CD8 T lymphocytes from Balb or Xid mice previously infected with E. 360 cuniculi (Infected) were co-cultured with macrophages and challenged with E. cuniculi. 361 Statistical analysis: paired t-tests were conducted in triplicate; *** p < 0.001 and **** p 362 < 0.0001. 363 364 365 366 CD8 T lymphocytes from Infected Xid mice showed low viability and proliferation 367 The viability of CD8 T lymphocytes from WT or Xid uninfected was greater than 90%. 368 (Fig. 5) The highest percentage of live CD8 T cells was recorded in cultured Xid mice 369 (Fig. 5B). We observed a predominance of necrosis with a type of cell death associated 370 with a decrease in CD8 T lymphocytes, WT vs Xid (Fig. 5C). CD8 T lymphocytes 371 obtained from previously infected WT or Xid in coculture with macrophages 372 demonstrated lower viability, between 75 and 85%, with the percentage of necrosis being 373 14% to 16% and 18 to 22%, observed respectively in WT and Xid (Fig. 5E, 5F ,5G),

374 although the percentage of apoptosis was higher (2%) in lymphocytes from the mice in 375 the Xid group (Fig. 5H). 376 377 Figure 5. Viability analysis of E. cuniculi-challenged macrophages co-cultured with 378 primed or unprimed CD8 T lymphocytes. 379 (A-D) Macrophages challenged with E. cuniculi were co-cultured for 36 h with CD8 T 380 lymphocytes collected from uninfected Balb/c (WT) mice and Xid mice. (E-H) 381 Macrophages challenged with E. cuniculi were co-cultured for 36 h with CD8 T 382 lymphocytes collected from E. cuniculi-infected Balb/c (WT) mice and Xid mice. (A) 383 The number of macrophages. (B) The percentage of living macrophages. (C) The 384 percentage of macrophages undergoing necrosis. (D) The percentage of macrophages 385 undergoing apoptosis. (E) The number of macrophages. (F) The percentage of living 386 macrophages. (G) The percentage of macrophages undergoing necrosis. (H) The 387 percentage of macrophages undergoing apoptosis. Statistical analysis: paired t-tests were 388 conducted in triplicate; * p < 0.05 and **** p < 0.0001. 389 390 The proliferation rate was higher in CD8+ T lymphocytes from uninfected WT mice 391 compared to that of the CD8+ T lymphocytes from other experimental groups. This 392 finding was confirmed by the low mean CFSE fluorescence intensity (MIF CFSE) 393 observed in this group (Fig. 6). Our results suggested that CD8 T lymphocytes from Xid 394 mice showed low proliferation irrespective of the presence of microsporidia. In infected 395 WT mice, the number of CFSE low lymphocytes from infected mice was much lower and 396 the presence of the pathogen probably decreased cell proliferation as well as increased 397 death from necrosis. 398

Statistical analysis: paired t-tests were 409 conducted in triplicate; *p < 0.05 and **** p < 0.0001. 410 411 CD8 T cells from uninfected WT mice with high expression of CD69 and Lamp-1 412 activation increased the microbicidal action of macrophages 413 The expression of CD69 selectin was higher in CD8 T lymphocytes from WT mice 414 compared to that in the lymphocytes from Xid mice, in the uninfected and infected groups 415 (Fig. 7A, 7B). These results suggested that B-1 cells, abundant in WT mice and deficient 416 in Xid mice, probably influenced the expression of co-stimulatory molecules, such as 417 CD69 in CD8 T lymphocytes. These findings explained the lower resistance of Xid mice 418 to encephalitozoonosis described by our group (Langanke et al., 2017). We found that the 419 expression of Lamp-1 increased in the lymphocytes of uninfected WT mice (Fig. 7A, 7B). 420 We examined the correlation between the co-stimulatory molecules CD62 x CD107 421 (Lamp-1) and CD62 x CD69 and found an inversely proportional relationship, i.e., the 422 expression of CD62L decreased as the expression of CD107 or CD69 increased on the

423 surface of CD8 T lymphocytes. For the first time, we illustrated the dynamics of the 424 expression of activation molecules on the surface of lymphocytes in encephalitozoonosis. 425 426 Figure 7. Expression of surface activation molecules and intracellular interferon in 427 CD8 T lymphocytes from Balb (WT) and Xid mice not infected (Uninfected) or 428 infected (Infected) with E. cuniculi spores. 429 (A) Analysis of the expression of the selectins CD62L, Lamp 1, and CD69 on the surface 430 of CD8+ T lymphocytes from the spleen of uninfected Balb/c and Xid mice that were co431 cultured with E. cuniculi infected macrophages. (B) Analysis of the expression of the 432 selectins CD62L, Lamp 1, and CD69 on the surface of CD8+ T lymphocytes from the 433 spleen of Balb/c mice previously infected with E. cuniculi and co-cultured with E. 434 cuniculi-infected macrophages. (C) The expression of selectins CD62L (positive or 435 negative) x CD69 or CD62L (positive or negative) x Lamp 1 on the surface of CD8+ T 436 lymphocytes from the spleen of uninfected Balb/c or Xid mice and infected Balb or Xid 437 mice. (D) The intracellular expression of INF-γ in CD8+ T lymphocytes from the spleen 438 of uninfected Balb/c and Xid mice or Balb/c and Xid mice previously infected with E. 439 cuniculi, all of which were co-cultured with macrophages infected with E. cuniculi. 440 Statistical analysis: paired t-tests were conducted; *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001, 441 and ****p < 0.0001 442 443 444 Discussion 445 Several researchers have found that B-1 cells participate in the response mediated by T 446 lymphocytes, for example, in immediate or delayed hypersensitivity reaction [27, 28] and 447 allograft rejection [25]. B-1 cells can also promote the activation of T lymphocytes and
under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license. preprint (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright

20
448 the production of IFN-γ by adoptively transferred T lymphocytes [26]. Our group found 449 that intraperitoneal infection of Xid mice with E. cuniculi resulted in an increase in CD8+ 450 T lymphocytes in the spleen and peritoneum, although these mice showed a greater range 451 of clinical signs and fungal burden, which indicated lower resistance to infection [21, 23]. 452 In Xid mice infected orally with E. cuniculi, the decrease in the number of CD8+ T cells 453 in the spleen and peritoneum was associated with a decrease in the content of serum IFN454 γ. These findings indicated that the resistance to infection was low [22]. 455 In this study, we found that CD8 T lymphocytes from WT (naïve) mice showed high 456 proliferative capacity, a high percentage of CD69 activation molecules, a low mortality 457 rate, and high microbicidal activity when cultured with macrophages. These results 458 suggested that B-1 cells present in Balb mice potentiated the cytotoxic activity of 459 lymphocytes. However, CD8 T cells from Xid mice (deficient in B-1 cells) proliferated 460 less. They exhibited lower expression of activation molecules and lower microbicidal 461 activity of macrophages in co-cultures. Our findings suggested that the presence of B-1 462 cells (in Balb mice) or their deficiency (in Xid mice) altered the cytotoxic function of 463 CD8 T lymphocytes. These changes could explained why Xid mice showed low 464 resistance to E. cuniculi infection, although the population of CD8 T cells was quite large. 465 Our results were similar to those of studies in which B1-cells were found to potentiate the 466 activity of CD8 T lymphocytes [25, 26, 27, 28]. Thus, the relationship between 467 lymphocytes/B-1 cells/macrophages might be linked to functional factors involving 468 complex signaling pathways. 469 The expression of CD69 in infiltrating lymphocytes in inflamed tissues is a marker of 470 different signaling pathways, which can regulate tissue retention, metabolism, and their 471 activated phenotype [29]. CD69 expression is rapidly induced on the surface of T 472 lymphocytes after the interaction between TCR and CD3, and was responsible for

The copyright holder for thisthis version posted November 22, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.11.22.568300doi: bioRxiv preprint
21
473 activates cytokines, polyclonal antibodies, and mitogens [30, 31]. Consistent with this 474 information, we found that CD8 T lymphocytes from WT mice showed higher expression 475 of CD69 and were associated with an increase in the microbicidal activity of macrophages 476 infected with E. cuniculi. The proliferation of CD8 T lymphocytes in this group of mice 477 was also higher, probably due a mitogenic stimulus. However, the reduction in the 478 microbicidal activity of macrophages co-cultured with CD8+CD69low T lymphocytes was 479 determined by the high proliferation of spores recovered from these assays. These 480 findings confirmed that a positive relationship occurred between CD69 expression in 481 CD8 T cells and macrophage stimulation, as recorded in tumor macrophages (TAM) [32].
482 The CD8 T lymphocytes obtained from infected Xid mice (primed) with E. cuniculi 483 showed a higher mortality rate due to necrosis and less for apoptosis. A similar finding 484 was recorded for macrophages co-cultured with these lymphocytes. In another study, we 485 showed that macrophages infected with E. cuniculi have a higher rate of apoptosis, which 486 matched the findings described here [33]. The natural response of an infected cell is to 487 undergo apoptosis to prevent the pathogen from multiplying and spreading. However, 488 apoptosis can act as a mechanism to evade the immune response; for example, 489 Encephalitozoon can suppress apoptosis, as found in Vero cells, by inhibiting the 490 cleavage of caspase-3, phosphorylation, and translocation of p53 [34]. We also found that 491 E. cuniculi can exploit efferocytosis to enter the host cell, multiply, and spread, as well 492 as, modulate to a less inflamed environment. These changes act as a favorable mechanism 493 for evading immunity [33]. 494 We also found that lymphocytes from previously infected Xid mice showed higher 495 expression of CD107, demonstrating their ability to function against E. cuniculi. Lamp-1 496 (lysosome-associated membrane protein CD107a) is predominantly expressed 497 intracellularly, but after activation, it can be expressed on the cell surface. LAMP-1
under 17 USC 105 and is also made available for use under a CC0 license. preprint (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. This article is a US Government work. It is not subject to copyright
The copyright holder for thisthis version posted November 22, 2023. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.11.22.568300doi: bioRxiv preprint
22
498 comprises 50% of all lysosomal membrane proteins and is widely used as a cell surface 499 marker of lymphocyte activation and degranulation. Additionally, LAMP-1 is a 500 physiologically essential protein involved in stabilizing lysosomes and regulating 501 autophagy to prevent embryonic lethality [35, 36, 37]. The expression of CD107 is 502 associated with a decrease in the expression of CD62L. Also, the elimination of CD62L 503 and changes in the cytoskeleton are associated with an increase in the lytic activity of T 504 cells [38]. We hypothesized that higher expression of CD107 and proliferative activity 505 might explain the high microbicidal activity exerted by macrophages co-cultured with 506 Xid lymphocytes previously infected with E. cuniculi, considering that memory CD8 T 507 cells have greater potential for division, high chance of survival, and low effector activity. 508 In conclusion, our results suggest that the absence of B-1 cells in Xid mice might be 509 associated with the lower expression of activating molecules in CD8+ T lymphocytes and 510 their cytotoxic activity. However, after a previous infection with E. cuniculi, CD8 T 511 lymphocytes were more effective in killing macrophages infected with E. cuniculi. 512
